chapter.title: Conjunctions
chapter.para: A conjunction is a word that joins other words, phrases, parts of sentences, or sentences together.

listitem.para: Usually joins two positive or two negative ideas.
Used to connect two opposing statements.
Demonstrates an effect or a result, similar to then in an if/then statement.

section.title: Transforming Conjunctions into Simple Sentences
section.para: Conjunctions are an important part of effective writing, but they add complexity to sentence structure. When writing technical documentation, analyze whether a conjunction makes a sentence more or less clear than two separate statements.
This sentence can be understood, eventually, but it's confusing:

informalexample.para: Foo2Bar is a framework that makes it easy to create application images, and takes application source code as an input, and produces a new image that runs the assembled application in an isolated sandbox.

section.para: See how much clearer it is when written as three separate sentences:

informalexample.para: Foo2Bar is a framework that makes it easy to create application images. It takes application source code to produce an executable image. Foo2Bar images run in an isolated sandbox for increased security.

To distribute your modifications, gather the configuration files, documentation files, all build materials, including build scripts and scripts needed to dynamically generate makefiles, and compiled binaries, and create a tar archive, or use the foopkg command on the parent directory.

section.para: This becomes much clearer when rewritten with fewer conjunctions:

informalexample.para: There are two ways to distribute your modifications. You can create a tar archive manually or you can use the foopkg command. For each, you must include all compiled binaries, configuration files, documentation, build scripts, and scripts to dynamically generate makefiles.

section.title: Choosing the Right Conjunctions
section.para: Sometimes conjunctions are the right choice, and in those cases you must choose the correct conjunction.
The but conjunction is very inflexible. It is appropriate when the two statements being connected are exclusive of one another, These two examples have very different meanings:

informalexample.para: A car can drive but it cannot fly.

section.para: Most importantly, but implies that two statements are opposed even if they are not. Using but incorrectly confuses readers. For example, if you write:

informalexample.para: Linux is open source but it is a stable, Enterprise-ready platform.

section.para: A reader probably interprets it to mean that Linux is Enterprise-ready in spite of it being open source. What you actually mean is that Linux is both open source and Enterprise-ready.

informalexample.para: Linux is open source and is a stable, Enterprise-ready platform.

section.para: The and conjunction connects two equally true or equally false statements into one:

informalexample.para: That hat is not red and it is not mine.
This fedora is red and it is mine.

section.para: The or conjunction implies a choice between the two statements it connects:

informalexample.para: Run the DHCP daemon embedded on the router or run your own on a server.

section.para: In the preceding statement, it's significant that you can use either the embedded DHCP server or your own, because using both could cause conflicts severe enough to bring down your network. It would be inaccurate to use a different conjunction:

informalexample.para: Run the DHCP daemon embedded on the router and run your own on a server.

section.para: In fact, for added emphasis, you can use either:

informalexample.para: Run either the DHCP daemon embedded on the router or run your own on a server.

section.para: The so conjunction connects causes and effects:

informalexample.para: &RHELX; is the latest release. This server is running &RHEL6;, so it needs to be updated.
This server is not running firewalld or SELinux, so it does not pass my security audit.

section.title: Exercise
section.para: Practice using the correct conjunction, or rewrite to use no conjunction:

listitem.para: Linux is an excellent platform for development, but it is an excellent platform for deployment.

Security-enhanced Linux (SELinux) is an implementation of a mandatory access control mechanism in the Linux kernel. It is an important part of system security. Do not disable SELinux, so use the setenforce command to put SELinux into permissive mode temporarily.
